misconceptions.name: Implements a different input specification (3 doubles for v0, v1, t instead of 5 integers)
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers as required to compute the sum of even numbers, the program prompts for and reads three double values (v0, v1, t) corresponding to a physics average-acceleration problem. This means the program solves a completely different task and never obtains the data needed for the required even-sum computation. Rubric impact for this criterion: 0/1 points, because the student does not read 5 integers at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for v0, v1, and t, reading them as doubles, and then compute average acceleration; that is the intended assignment here.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., using nextInt()), because the goal is to process those 5 integer values to compute the sum of only the even ones. The prompt should describe 5 integers, not v0, v1, and t, and the input count and types must match the problem statement.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions 'Enter v0, v1, and t' instead of 'Enter 5 integers'
Program calls nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times
No way for the user to input 5 integers, so the required computation is impossible
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different textbook problem (average acceleration) instead of the specified even-sum problem, indicating a misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design your input around it: prompt for 'Enter 5 integers:', then either call nextInt() five times or use a loop that runs 5 times and reads an int each iteration.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to input specifications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt string and variable names (v0, v1, t) plus the use of doubles clearly match a standard acceleration example, not the described even-sum problem.

evidence.note: Program prompts for three values (v0, v1, t) and reads three doubles with nextDouble(), rather than reading 5 integers as required.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The problem requires processing 5 inputs, which is naturally and typically done with a loop. The submitted code contains no for, while, or do-while loop and instead performs a single fixed calculation based on three values. As a result, it cannot iterate over 5 numbers to accumulate anything. Rubric impact for this criterion: 0/1 points, because there is no loop structure at all for handling multiple inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to read a small fixed set of values (v0, v1, t) and plug them into a single formula; a loop is not needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process 5 integers in the same way (checking each for evenness and adding it to a running total), a loop is the appropriate tool. A for- or while-loop should repeat the read-and-check logic 5 times.
symptoms: No loop constructs (for, while, do-while) appear in main
Program executes a single arithmetic expression instead of repeated processing for 5 values
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a different physics formula problem, they structured the program around one direct computation instead of a repeated-input pattern that the even-sum problem calls for.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Refactor main so that it contains a loop that runs exactly 5 times. In each iteration, read one integer and apply the even-number check and accumulation logic inside the loop body.
related_concepts: Using loops to process collections of inputs
Designing loop bounds from problem requirements (5 iterations)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program body is straight-line code; there is no loop keyword and no repetition of input operations corresponding to 5 values.

evidence.note: Main consists only of straight-line code; there is no for, while, or do-while loop to iterate over 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number conditional logic
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether any number is even; there is no use of the modulus operator (%) or any conditional related to evenness. Instead, it directly computes (v1 - v0) / t. Therefore, it cannot possibly filter numbers based on even/odd parity as required. Rubric impact for this criterion: 0/1 points, because no conditional for even checking is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this task, I only need to compute a single arithmetic formula (average acceleration) and do not need to perform any conditional checks like even/odd.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only the even numbers, the program must test each input integer with a condition such as if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the sum. This conditional is central to the specification.
symptoms: No occurrences of the % operator in the code
No if or equivalent conditional that references evenness or parity
Final result is based solely on (v1 - v0) / t, not on any property of multiple input integers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student focused on implementing the average-acceleration formula and never implemented any logic to distinguish even numbers from odd ones.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, add an if statement: if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }. Make sure to use the modulus operator (%) to test for even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The provided code has no if statements and no % operator, so the required even-check conditional is clearly absent.

evidence.snippet:
double average_acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + average_acceleration);
evidence.note: Instead of any conditional even check like if (n % 2 == 0), the code directly computes an unrelated formula and prints it.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator or even-number sum; prints unrelated acceleration result
misconceptions.description: The code never declares or updates a running sum of numbers. It computes a single value average_acceleration and prints it with the message 'The average acceleration is ...'. It therefore does not accumulate the sum of even numbers, nor does it print 'Sum of even numbers: ...' or any equivalent. Rubric impact for this criterion: 0/1 points, because there is no accumulator pattern and the printed result is for a different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The required output is the average acceleration computed as (v1 - v0) / t, printed with a message describing acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer variable (e.g., sum) initialized to 0, add each even input to this sum, and after processing all 5 integers, print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum. That accumulator pattern is the target behavior.
symptoms: No variable named sum or similar accumulator present
No repeated addition based on input values
Output message refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
Final result is unrelated to any sum over 5 integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Again, the student appears to have implemented the acceleration example rather than the even-sum problem, so they use a single expression instead of a running total and print a physics-related message.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0; before your loop. Inside the loop, when a number is even, do sum += n;. After the loop, print System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is only one computed value (average_acceleration) and one println, both clearly targeted at the acceleration problem; no sum or related operations are present.

evidence.note: Shows a single computed value and message for 'average acceleration', with no accumulator variable or sum-related output.
